author: arnetheduck
content: when the `status` message is exchanged is up to each client as it sees fit - generally, there's no reason to exchange them unless you want to sync with that client - under normal operation, you're getting everything you need from gossip, so it's only while syncing that you might be interested in status. when you're syncing, you're transferring blocks - if a block is 10kb and you add 100 bytes of status every time you request a block, that's a 1% overhead. Most of the time though, you'll likely be requesting a range of blocks at a time, driving the status down further.

author: arnetheduck
content: for sync, you can probably get away with updating it once per epoch, given that finalization only happens then - whatever information is in `head` is likely to change while your request is in flight, so it doesn't matter that much if it's 1, 2, or 5 blocks behind as long as it's within the finalized period

author: arnetheduck
content: that said, we're anticipating a few changes to both the status and the sync protocol as we gain experience with the messages - the current spec is a first cut meant as a starting point for discussion - it should be good enough to use as a baseline from which quantified changes can be made

author: arnetheduck
content: we have one such change lined up: we currently require that block requests send at least one `response_chunk` - we'll likely be proposing that this requirement be dropped

author: arnetheduck
content: consider a block range request: it might end up with no blocks because it's slot-based: currently if the request selects an empty range, there's no way to respond "correctly" - it can be resolved either by having no `response_chunk` or having a special "no data" error code, or potentially including a "null" marker in a "success" chunk. the first option seems the easiest and most consistent.

author: arnetheduck
content: coming back to `status`, the general idea in most protocols is that you want the cost for a potential attacker to be at least as high as that on the node - a classic example of this is that the listener is typically silent until the initiator provides some information - in libp2p, there will be a protocol negotiation taking place early on, with cipher suites and network protocol version / capabilities etc - it's only after that negotiation has taken place that `status` becomes relevant
